title: Leading Cause of Death in Children Since 2020 - Truth or Fiction?
summary: In 2020, firearms became the leading cause of death for children and adolescents in the United States, surpassing vehicular accidents for the first time in decades. This shift was verified by a letter from University of Michigan researchers published in the New England Journal of Medicine, which analyzed CDC data showing a significant increase in firearm-related deaths. The data revealed a 33.4% increase in firearm homicides and a 1.1% increase in suicides from 2019 to 2020. This trend is part of a longer-term increase in firearm mortality among children, indicating a failure to protect this population from preventable deaths despite recent research funding aimed at firearm injury prevention. Previously, motor vehicle accidents had been the leading cause of death among children and adolescents for over sixty years.

title: Firearms were the leading cause of death in children in 2020 ...
summary: In 2020, firearms became the leading cause of death among children under the age of 19, overtaking motor vehicle accidents, which held that position for the previous 60 years. According to research from the New England Journal of Medicine, overall firearm-related deaths rose by 13.5% from 2019 to 2020, with deaths among children aged 1 to 19 increasing by nearly 30%. The study cites a total of 45,222 firearm-related deaths in the U.S. in 2020, with approximately 4,357 being among children. Although the COVID-19 pandemic may have influenced this increase, the specific reasons remain unclear. Unlike adults, where the majority of gun-related deaths are due to suicide, child firearm deaths are primarily homicides. Despite mass shootings receiving significant media attention, they represent a small fraction of gun-related child fatalities, which typically occur in smaller, daily incidents. The disparity between the decrease in motor vehicle deaths and the rise in firearm deaths underscores the lack of similar scientific and policy interventions in addressing firearm violence.

title: Guns now the leading cause of death for US children, CDC says
summary: Firearms became the leading cause of death for U.S. children and adolescents in 2020, surpassing motor vehicle deaths due to a significant increase in gun-related fatalities. According to CDC data analyzed in the New England Journal of Medicine, there were 4,368 child gun deaths, mainly homicides, followed by suicides. Meanwhile, motor vehicle deaths have decreased since 1999, reaching just over 5 deaths per 100,000 children in 2020. The CDC defines children and adolescents as those 19 years old or younger.

title: Are firearms the leading cause of death in children? - Poynter
summary: According to CDC data from 2020, firearms were the leading cause of death among children and adolescents ages 1 to 18 and 1 to 19. A report by the Johns Hopkins Center for Gun Violence Solutions also found that gun violence was the leading cause of death for those under age 25, with 4,357 deaths among children and teens ages 1 to 19 attributed to firearms. If infants are included in the analysis, congenital abnormalities surpass firearm deaths among children up to age 18. Senator Chuck Schumer highlighted this issue in a speech, citing the need for tighter gun laws. The findings are supported by multiple analyses of CDC data, indicating that Schumer's claim is mostly true, though it requires clarification considering the distinct causes of death for infants.

title: Current Causes of Death in Children and Adolescents in the United ...
summary: In 2020, firearm-related injuries became the leading cause of death among U.S. children and adolescents (ages 1-19), surpassing motor vehicle crashes. This shift was driven by a 29.5% increase in firearm-related deaths (including homicide, suicide, unintentional, and undetermined causes) in this age group, significantly higher than the increase observed in the general population. The rise was consistent across most demographics. Additionally, drug overdoses and poisonings saw a sharp 83.6% increase, making them the third leading cause of death among children and adolescents. These trends highlight significant shifts in mortality during the early COVID-19 pandemic, emphasizing the urgent need for preventive measures against firearm violence and unintentional poisonings.

title: The Major Causes of Death in Children and Adolescents in the United ...
summary: In 2016, the leading cause of death among children and adolescents (ages 1–19) in the United States was injury-related, accounting for over 60% of all deaths in this age group. Motor vehicle crashes were the top cause, responsible for 20% of deaths, followed by firearm-related injuries, which accounted for 15%. Among firearm-related deaths, 59% were homicides, 35% suicides, and 4% unintentional injuries. Firearms were a particularly significant cause of intentional deaths during adolescence, with most intentional firearm deaths resulting from homicide.Malignant neoplasms were the third leading cause of death (9%), followed by suffocation (7%). Causes of death varied with age: younger children (1–4 years) most often died from drowning, while adolescents (10–19 years) were more likely to die from motor vehicle crashes, firearms, and suffocation. Intent also shifted with age; unintentional injuries were more common in younger children, while intentional injuries (homicide and suicide) predominated among adolescents. In 2016, firearm-related injuries were the second leading cause of death among children and adolescents in the U.S., accounting for 15.4% of injury-related deaths, with a mortality rate of 4.02 per 100,000. Firearm deaths exceeded those from malignant neoplasms, suffocation, and drowning. From 2013 to 2016, firearm-related mortality increased by 28%, driven by a 32% rise in homicides and a 26% rise in suicides. The U.S. firearm death rate for children and adolescents was significantly higher than rates in other high-income countries, being 36.5 times the average of 12 high-income nations. Comparatively, motor vehicle crashes, the leading cause of death, had a decreasing trend over time due to improved safety measures.
